Package io.github.ajevans.dbcode.data.io

Interface IDataSupplier

All Known Implementing Classes:
CruTs2pt1Supplier
public interface IDataSupplier
Interface for classes that supply data.

Note that classes must have a default constructor only, for building into automatic loading systems.

Each source (e.g. a directory) may have a set of record holders (e.g. files) each containing records (e.g. rows).

Note that exceptions should generally be re-thrown from implementations where not dealt with, allowing users of implementations to deal with the exceptions as part of a broader system. Exception messages should therefore be user friendly.

Author:
Andy Evans
Version: 1.0 28 Feb 2021

  • Method Details

    • initialise

      void initialise() throws DataException
      Should set up the data supplier ready to read data.

      Should create the relevant internal data structures in preparation for reading the data, including reading in and parsing file headers.

      Note that this method is kept separate from setSource to enable piped data processing implementations where a series of supplies and consumers set up prior to activation.

      If a source path and record holder names haven't been set using the setSource / setRecordHolderNames methods, this method should throw a DataException.

      Throws:
      DataException - If issues arise.

    • getDataset

      IDataset getDataset()
      Should get the dataset, which may or may not be empty.

      This method allows for a data pull directly by data consumers where data definitely fits in memory, but also allows access to an empty dataset set up by an initialise call so callers can interrogate it for prospective data fields and metadata. At minimum, therefore, implementations should demand initialise called first.

      Implementations should require a call to readData first to load the data into the supplier if the caller needs the data.

      Primitives should be boxed.

      Returns:
      IDataset IDataset of data or null if no data.
      See Also:
      pushData()

    • readData

      void readData() throws DataException
      Should fill the dataset with data.

      Implementations should require a call to initialise first to set up the internal data structures necessary - this allows callers to getDataset to gain a dataset containing just metadata and field information in preparation for any data arriving.

      Throws:
      DataException - If there is is an issue - for example, the data needs to be sent piecemeal.

    • pushData

      void pushData() throws DataException
      This method should start the data supplier pushing collections of records to one or more registered consumers.

      This observer push pathway is for situations where memory is low / data is large. IDataConsumers should be able to register for push data using addDataListener. Implementers should call consumer's load(ArrayList<IRecord> records) method when records are available.

      As the active class in the observer pattern, implementers of this method may like to force a garbage collection to free up resources after the push.

      Throws:
      DataException - If there is is an issue - for example, the data can only be supplied in one go.
      See Also:
      IDataConsumer.load(ArrayList<IRecord> records), addDataListener(IDataConsumer consumer)

    • setSource

      void setSource​(java.io.File source) throws DataException
      Should set up the data source path as a File object.

      If not called, initialise should generate a default path when called.

      Parameters:
      source - Source file to read.
      Throws:
      DataException - If issues arise.
      To Do:
      For a piping system, add version for streaming.

    • getSource

      java.io.File getSource()
      Should gets the source that will be read.

      This will be, e.g. a directory. Filenames should be supplied through setRecordStoreNames to allow multiple files to be read.

      Returns:
      source Source file to read.

    • setRecordHolderNames

      void setRecordHolderNames​(java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.String> recordHolderNames) throws DataException
      Should set the record holder names (e.g. filenames) for the store (e.g. directory).

      Record holders within a source will be, e.g. tables within a database or files within a directory.

      If these names aren't set via this method, they should be drawn from defaults or the dataset in initialise.

      If set here directly (for example, the user enters the name/s), it is the implementers responsibility to make sure the number of record holders named and number supplied in the source to initialise match up or initialise should throw an exception.

      Parameters:
      recordHolderNames - Names of record holders to connect to.
      Throws:
      DataException - When issues arise.
      See Also:
      initialise()

    • getRecordHolderNames

      java.util.ArrayList<java.lang.String> getRecordHolderNames()
      Should gets the names of source record holders to read.
      Returns:
      recordHolderNames ArrayList of names.

    • addDataListener

      void addDataListener​(IDataConsumer consumer)
      This method should register a consumer with a supplier for push data.
      Parameters:
      consumer - Consumer to push the data to.
      See Also:
      IDataConsumer.load(ArrayList<IRecord> records), pushData()

    • addReportingListener

      void addReportingListener​(IReportingListener reportingListener)
      For objects wishing to get progress reports on data reading.
      Parameters:
      reportingListener - Object wishing to gain reports.
      See Also:
      IReportingListener

    • connectSource

      void connectSource​(int index) throws DataException
      Should connect to a record holder (e.g. file) in the current source (directory).
      Parameters:
      index - Index of record holder to connect to in collection set using setRecordHolderNames.
      Throws:
      DataException - If there is an issue.

    • disconnectSource

      void disconnectSource() throws DataException
      Should disconnect from current source and any files.

      Implementations should use this as an opportunity to force a garbage collection.

      Throws:
      DataException - If there is an issue.
